headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you look, Frank -- if you look at -- if you remember, we were planning, as we said in the second quarter call, about $7 million spending for the boiler repair and plant outage. We weren't expecting last part of that to be in the third quarter and the s
componenttext: If you look, Frank -- if you look at -- if you remember, we were planning, as we said in the second quarter call, about $7 million spending for the boiler repair and plant outage. We weren't expecting last part of that to be in the third quarter and the smaller part to be in the fourth quarter. For operational and commercial reasons, we have shifted that towards the beginning of the fourth quarter. The good news is that all is well. The boiler is repaired and functioning and the outage is behind us. We do believe that the range we gave to you of $4 million to $7 million is on the high side of that range spent over 2 quarters, and it's about 1/3 in the third quarter and about 2/3 in the fourth quarter.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: All right, terrific. So everything is complete now, so that's behind us. All right, great, and I understand that you're not going to comment on the 2 parallel pads for the phosphates business in Europe, but I just wanted to ask is fixing that business and
componenttext: All right, terrific. So everything is complete now, so that's behind us. All right, great, and I understand that you're not going to comment on the 2 parallel pads for the phosphates business in Europe, but I just wanted to ask is fixing that business and keeping it in a portfolio, that's not one of the 2 parallel pads. Is it?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It is not.
componenttext: It is not.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: All right, terrific. And lastly, I noted that in the Ag is you have sales moving up for the year in excess of what your EBIT will be moving up. Can you just spend another minute or 2 by talking about why that would be?
componenttext: All right, terrific. And lastly, I noted that in the Ag is you have sales moving up for the year in excess of what your EBIT will be moving up. Can you just spend another minute or 2 by talking about why that would be?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Frank. There is 2 major reasons for which we do have such a situation. First of all, remember that business from an earnings standpoint was penalized in the first half of the year on inventory cost. And there was about a $20 million over 2 quarters o
componenttext: Yes, Frank. There is 2 major reasons for which we do have such a situation. First of all, remember that business from an earnings standpoint was penalized in the first half of the year on inventory cost. And there was about a $20 million over 2 quarters of penalty at the gross margin level. It's purely accounting. That has nothing to do with the quality of the performance or the sales of the operations of -- or the operations of the business. Second of all, we have made a very conscious decision to increase our spending in market innovation and technology innovation for growth. So when you get into the year, those 2 reasons would create lower earning growth than sales growth. We do believe it's going to be a situations that's got a chance where we will be starting next year able to leverage top line growth into earnings growth.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John McNulty from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John McNulty from Credit Suisse.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a few quick questions. On the specialty chemical front, with what we've seen in terms of lithium volumes and maybe the pricing coming back, and BioPolymer's looking like it was pretty good. I'm surprised the growth was maybe as moderate as it was in
componenttext: Just a few quick questions. On the specialty chemical front, with what we've seen in terms of lithium volumes and maybe the pricing coming back, and BioPolymer's looking like it was pretty good. I'm surprised the growth was maybe as moderate as it was in the quarter. Can you give us a little bit of color as to what might have driven that?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, you're talking about the growth year-on-year sequentially?
componenttext: John, you're talking about the growth year-on-year sequentially?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Year-on-year.
componenttext: Year-on-year.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Year-on-year, yes. There was a dropoff -- actually it was one main reason. If you look at our specialty chemical business, this business is made of 3 businesses. We do have the Lithium business, we have the food business and we have the pharma business. Y
componenttext: Year-on-year, yes. There was a dropoff -- actually it was one main reason. If you look at our specialty chemical business, this business is made of 3 businesses. We do have the Lithium business, we have the food business and we have the pharma business. Year-on-year, the Lithium business was up 14%, well within expectations. The pharma business was up 9%, well within expectations. The food business was only up 4%, which is below what we would be expecting, and there is one main reason for that. As you know, we have an acquisition we made of ISC [ph] and this year, we completed the integration process of that acquisition, creating some lower capacity because we faced some problem in transferring the process and moving that to our North American plant. So what happened in this quarter, we will operate in growth not by customer demand. We actually were operating through the quarter with a significant backlog that we were limited in our ability to supply product to customers because of those integration issues. We do have worked those issues very hard, and we do believe that they are very close to being and we can resume normal growth very quickly.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. That color is very helpful. Second question would be in the soda ash business and maybe it's 2 parts to it. First part would be on the pricing. I know you've announced a couple of price increases. Given kind of what is going on in Asia with t
componenttext: Okay, great. That color is very helpful. Second question would be in the soda ash business and maybe it's 2 parts to it. First part would be on the pricing. I know you've announced a couple of price increases. Given kind of what is going on in Asia with the weakness or weakness in supply outside of Asia because of the energy issues that you mentioned, how should we think about pricing in terms of where you can go and if the full increase of that you've announced would all likely to stick or how should we think about that?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let's break it down into 2 categories. There is the domestic market and, as we said, we have to increase for a total of $22 to $20 per ton and announced a while ago that we grew $30 per ton increase for our export market. Now for the domestic market, as w
componenttext: Let's break it down into 2 categories. There is the domestic market and, as we said, we have to increase for a total of $22 to $20 per ton and announced a while ago that we grew $30 per ton increase for our export market. Now for the domestic market, as we said before, we are operating very near to full capacity, so we are just getting right now into contract negotiation. It's always hard before you negotiate your contract to know where you will end up and how much of the price increase we'll see. Nevertheless, looking at the near full capacity utilization in North America, we are getting into those negotiations quite confident. Regarding the export market, we do have many reasons to believe that will be successful. I think we're seeing more and more limitation on Chinese export capacity because of their pricing and cost situation. So we do believe that the price increase in will result in some success. Once again, this price increase for us applied to Latin America where most of the contracts are annual so hard to know when we get closer to January. We might actually in Asia, actually in China, see some impact of price increase because we're operating on shorter-term contract in Asia and we might be able to see some improvement on the pricing situation for export in Asia outside of China. But really, the full impact, John, we will know that when we get closer to the month of December and January.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And just last question, same topic, with Solvay exiting ANSAC, what are your thoughts in terms of what that does overall to the competitive market?
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And just last question, same topic, with Solvay exiting ANSAC, what are your thoughts in terms of what that does overall to the competitive market?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: At this stage, I think life is going to change more for Solvay. It's going to change for us. We keep on going. We believe we are in a very strong position. ANSAC is doing a strategy on export. So we are not looking at that is very threatening or very much
componenttext: At this stage, I think life is going to change more for Solvay. It's going to change for us. We keep on going. We believe we are in a very strong position. ANSAC is doing a strategy on export. So we are not looking at that is very threatening or very much changing of the situation.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Kevin McCarthy of Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Kevin McCarthy of Bank of America.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you have an estimate of how much capacity, how much soda ash capacity would have been removed from the Chinese market? It seems that prices have gone parabolic there over the last 6 weeks or so.
componenttext: I was wondering if you have an estimate of how much capacity, how much soda ash capacity would have been removed from the Chinese market? It seems that prices have gone parabolic there over the last 6 weeks or so.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I need to ask Michael Wilson to answer that question.
componenttext: I need to ask Michael Wilson to answer that question.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kevin, I don't have the exact number for you in terms of the amount of capacity that's been taken off-line. Sometimes it's hard to track. We do know that at least 2 significant plants have been taken down we believe permanently and others have been curtai
componenttext: Kevin, I don't have the exact number for you in terms of the amount of capacity that's been taken off-line. Sometimes it's hard to track. We do know that at least 2 significant plants have been taken down we believe permanently and others have been curtailed, and a lot of this has to do with China and its targets for energy usage as a percentage of GDP. So there are a lot of restrictions in the third quarter. I think overall, China's operating at about 80% capacity utilization. But if you go into some of these provinces where they're really up against their targets, capacity and some plants is going to ratcheted back to 30%, 60%. So it's really hard to judge overall. What we do know is that exports from China year-on-year are down some 35%. So between the energy restrictions and between their inability to compete on price with ANSAC has been a significant impact in terms of our influence in the export market.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you look at your competition after soda ash, Michael, what's the approximate split of U.S. versus exports say year-to-date or over the last year or so?
componenttext: If you look at your competition after soda ash, Michael, what's the approximate split of U.S. versus exports say year-to-date or over the last year or so?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: About 52% of our total sales are in export markets either through ANSAC or direct.
componenttext: About 52% of our total sales are in export markets either through ANSAC or direct.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, and where is freight running to Asia these days?
componenttext: Okay, and where is freight running to Asia these days?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure that I have the exact number but freight has come down to Asia, which has benefited ANSAC. And as we look forward to 2011, we think freight again is going to be beneficial to ANSAC as well as our exports to Europe.
componenttext: I'm not sure that I have the exact number but freight has come down to Asia, which has benefited ANSAC. And as we look forward to 2011, we think freight again is going to be beneficial to ANSAC as well as our exports to Europe.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, last question, if I may. For Pierre, you made it clear that biopolymers is your top priority for M&A. I was wondering if you could just talk about the criteria for acquisitions that you're evaluating in terms of any color on timeframes for earni
componenttext: And then, last question, if I may. For Pierre, you made it clear that biopolymers is your top priority for M&A. I was wondering if you could just talk about the criteria for acquisitions that you're evaluating in terms of any color on timeframes for earnings accretion, multiple ranges, size of deals, that sort of thing?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, first of all, size of deal, we are looking in bolt-on, looking at RDEs expansion. I would say anything from companies which are running 10 million barrels in sales with good growth potential international expansion to $200 million, $300 million, $400
componenttext: Yes, first of all, size of deal, we are looking in bolt-on, looking at RDEs expansion. I would say anything from companies which are running 10 million barrels in sales with good growth potential international expansion to $200 million, $300 million, $400 million in sales will be the kind of bolt-on acquisition we would be looking at. What we would like to expect from the multiple standpoint is to make acquisition where past synergies multiple do not create dilution. And of course, we like the acquisition to be accretive very quickly first year, and if not, first year a year or 2 at the latest. From a strategy standpoint, we're looking at acquisition. If you look to have product line in the business where we do have higher market share in niche where we are very strong but pretty much limiting growth to whatever market growth we have. So our intent that we believe we could gain share at critical customer if we wouldn't increase acquisition in the market with other technologies than the one we do have today. So that's going to be operating. But once again, we thought through that very carefully. It's going to be small companies fitting our strategy. We are not going for any mean for last transformational deal. We do not believe in fit strategy and we deal with our successful business model.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Mike Harrison from First Analysis.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Mike Harrison from First Analysis.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about the raw material pressure that you noted in the BioPolymers business. What specific raw materials are higher? And do your contracts allow you to pass that through any capacity? Or is that going to create some margin pressure until ea
componenttext: I wanted to ask about the raw material pressure that you noted in the BioPolymers business. What specific raw materials are higher? And do your contracts allow you to pass that through any capacity? Or is that going to create some margin pressure until each of your contracts come up for renewal?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ted, first to address the raw material question. Ted?
componenttext: Yes, Ted, first to address the raw material question. Ted?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is Ted. We're seeing in BioPolymer pressure as raw materials going up both with our seaweed businesses specialty and in our pulp businesses. A number of our accounts customers in our seaweed businesses we have some pass-throughs or where we're
componenttext: Mike, this is Ted. We're seeing in BioPolymer pressure as raw materials going up both with our seaweed businesses specialty and in our pulp businesses. A number of our accounts customers in our seaweed businesses we have some pass-throughs or where we're actively raising prices to help that pass that through. In the pulp side, we have some of that. We also have contracts and it comes in different stages but they're not in every seaweed where we're seeing the prices coming up, but it's up and continuing we feel will grow for the next several months and increasing in pressure.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And can you talk a little bit, Ted, about what kind of flexibility you have to shift among different raw materials? I know you don't want to spend too much time sourcing things from different geographies again from that kind of thing. But are there specif
componenttext: And can you talk a little bit, Ted, about what kind of flexibility you have to shift among different raw materials? I know you don't want to spend too much time sourcing things from different geographies again from that kind of thing. But are there specific areas or regions where you're seeing the greatest pressure?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike, I think we have a number of flexibilities. And in the last several years, we feel we have a lot more capability to do that both in seaweeds. We have multiple geographies where we can get many of the seaweeds and we worked through that with many
componenttext: Yes, Mike, I think we have a number of flexibilities. And in the last several years, we feel we have a lot more capability to do that both in seaweeds. We have multiple geographies where we can get many of the seaweeds and we worked through that with many different freighters. In the pulp side, we have many alternatives that we continue to work on that area and that takes different amount of times between customers for qualification approval, but that's been a very successful strategy over the last several years for us to help mitigate some of the volatility in raw materials.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would like -- I mean it's very important raw material cost and when you look at the segment level, but I would still like to put the color on the numbers because company is one of the great strength even when there is additional. It's not like we are de
componenttext: I would like -- I mean it's very important raw material cost and when you look at the segment level, but I would still like to put the color on the numbers because company is one of the great strength even when there is additional. It's not like we are dependent on oil price with significant variation like some chemical company could be facing. Just to give you a sense, when we talk about a raw material impact year-to-date for business like BioPolymers, it is in mid-single digit. So you're talking about $5 million, $6 million, $7 million overall year-on-year kind of numbers. We're not something double-digit significant differences. We look at it because at the segment level, it's important. But in the big scheme of the company, those are not ups and downs.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then, I was also hoping to ask about the lithium market. And you talk about the supply and demand dynamics specifically in the butyllithium area and what kind of support you're seeing in the marketplace for pricing to offset some of the hi
componenttext: Understood. And then, I was also hoping to ask about the lithium market. And you talk about the supply and demand dynamics specifically in the butyllithium area and what kind of support you're seeing in the marketplace for pricing to offset some of the high electricity and other costs that you're seeing on the lithium specialty side?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike, it's Ted again. On butyllithium, which is our key downstream product in the Lithium business, we have been successful in seeing prices increases demand. Supply and demand are fairly imbalanced, and that improved over the last couple of years. W
componenttext: Yes, Mike, it's Ted again. On butyllithium, which is our key downstream product in the Lithium business, we have been successful in seeing prices increases demand. Supply and demand are fairly imbalanced, and that improved over the last couple of years. We are getting price increases in most markets today and continue to see steady growth for the business. So our profitability of this side of the business has been improving.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Peter Butler from Glenn Hill investment.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Peter Butler from Glenn Hill investment.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the superb look at your strategy. That was very helpful today, thanks. I have just 2 questions. What's your best guess given all the moving parts on how much of the earning swing you might have in soda ash next year versus this year?
componenttext: Thanks for the superb look at your strategy. That was very helpful today, thanks. I have just 2 questions. What's your best guess given all the moving parts on how much of the earning swing you might have in soda ash next year versus this year?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Peter, we are just in the process really of looking through all of that. We do have this very rigorous process. I have not myself yet seen the -- coming from each of the business units. We will start to have a good color by the middle of November and then
componenttext: Peter, we are just in the process really of looking through all of that. We do have this very rigorous process. I have not myself yet seen the -- coming from each of the business units. We will start to have a good color by the middle of November and then we'll have to work those numbers for board approval sometime around mid-December. So it's still work in progress. It depends a lot on volume but also on what do we believe will be happening on pricing, if it's very early now that we have not yet started negotiations. I'm not in a position to give you any color at this stage. I will need a few more weeks.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: You had Mark Douglas on your conference call the last several times, but I don't think he has said a word yet. Does Mr. Douglas have some observations he'd like to share today?
componenttext: You had Mark Douglas on your conference call the last several times, but I don't think he has said a word yet. Does Mr. Douglas have some observations he'd like to share today?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I am real. Thanks for the question. It observation is going forward as Pierre said is that my -- is to look at the procurement area and rapid developing economies and Pierre's already talked about that is a key part of our strategy going forward. So
componenttext: Well, I am real. Thanks for the question. It observation is going forward as Pierre said is that my -- is to look at the procurement area and rapid developing economies and Pierre's already talked about that is a key part of our strategy going forward. So I said I'll be talking about December 2 in New York and hopefully you'll hear a lot more details around procurement and other developing economies than, but rest assured the work is going forward.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next mission is from the line of Douglas Chudy from KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next mission is from the line of Douglas Chudy from KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess first, that you noted for BioPolymer you did receive a benefit from some productivity improvements. Can you give us a little bit more color here where you're driving these improvements and maybe some future potential?
componenttext: I guess first, that you noted for BioPolymer you did receive a benefit from some productivity improvements. Can you give us a little bit more color here where you're driving these improvements and maybe some future potential?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, most of the productivity improvement today are coming for unfortunately for also what is the reasons for some of the growth, mostly from integration of the acquisition, the ASP acquisitions. So those are mostly numbers which were announced and we ar
componenttext: Well, most of the productivity improvement today are coming for unfortunately for also what is the reasons for some of the growth, mostly from integration of the acquisition, the ASP acquisitions. So those are mostly numbers which were announced and we are just delivering on the integration cost savings from the ASP acquisition.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay so one time in nature versus kind of ongoing here, is the way to think about it?
componenttext: Okay so one time in nature versus kind of ongoing here, is the way to think about it?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, it's not going because once the compensation is done, we are shutting down the plant. So if you look at the performance we do have today, it will be sustained. We shut down plants from the former company required and consolidate manufacturing on singl
componenttext: No, it's not going because once the compensation is done, we are shutting down the plant. So if you look at the performance we do have today, it will be sustained. We shut down plants from the former company required and consolidate manufacturing on single plant. So those are ongoing saving now by seeing onetime, you will now realize versus this year the same amount the following year. It is correct, operating at a level where we are is good for the future.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just secondly, you noted again for the fourth quarter for Industrial Chemicals that you would see year-over-year pricing headwind. If I recall, I think the soda ash markets, pricing market was stabilized last year on the thi
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just secondly, you noted again for the fourth quarter for Industrial Chemicals that you would see year-over-year pricing headwind. If I recall, I think the soda ash markets, pricing market was stabilized last year on the third to fourth quarter. So would you actually start to see a positive year-over-year comp in terms of soda ash pricing?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think if you look, the pricing differential is decreasing each quarter, and I think it's not minor but really starting to be a much lower level in the fourth quarter and that will be turning going into first quarter next year.
componenttext: I think if you look, the pricing differential is decreasing each quarter, and I think it's not minor but really starting to be a much lower level in the fourth quarter and that will be turning going into first quarter next year.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your last question comes from the line of Dmitry Silverstein from Longbow Research.
componenttext: Your last question comes from the line of Dmitry Silverstein from Longbow Research.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Couple of questions as most of them have been answered. Number one, I know you guys are hedging and natural gas exposure about 80% and by this time of the year, you should be mostly hedged for 2011. So my question is what should our expectations be for na
componenttext: Couple of questions as most of them have been answered. Number one, I know you guys are hedging and natural gas exposure about 80% and by this time of the year, you should be mostly hedged for 2011. So my question is what should our expectations be for natural gas cost in 2011 versus 2010? And then, secondly, more of a strategic question along the same lines. Several companies in our space we have hedged natural gas in the past and proceeding is operating by row of inflation natural gas pricing have backed away from hedging given that the price of gas has declined and projections at least for the near term, midterm are for continuing benign kind of $4 maybe it's up $4 natural gas. So have you considered going away from your hedges or hedging less of your upcoming needs?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dmitry, this is Kim, and that's good question. As far as the first question on the hedging program, we are essentially complete. And natural gas that component of our energy costs represented by our natural gas will be a slight tailwind for us in 2011 ver
componenttext: Dmitry, this is Kim, and that's good question. As far as the first question on the hedging program, we are essentially complete. And natural gas that component of our energy costs represented by our natural gas will be a slight tailwind for us in 2011 versus 2010 but only slight. As you remember, quite significant tailwind for us in 2010 versus 2009. As it relates to your second question, we are going to do a fairly in-depth relook at our hedging strategies, both whether we should do them, the scope we should do the math and the duration if we continue that we would do the math. And I guess Peter Butler gave Mark a chance to say something but one of the things he's also going to look at and we're going to have procurement specialists in the energy area. And treasury in conjunction with procurement is going to relook at our hedging strategies going forward.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Very good, that's very helpful. And then switching gears to Industrial Chemicals business. Have your plans for the timing of the Granger restart changed given how much export volumes you're pushing out and the outlook for very strong volume growth in the
componenttext: Very good, that's very helpful. And then switching gears to Industrial Chemicals business. Have your plans for the timing of the Granger restart changed given how much export volumes you're pushing out and the outlook for very strong volume growth in the export market of Chinese continue to back away from it? Or are we still kind of looking for some time in the middle of next year as it is the most likely time frame?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're looking at an opening. It takes a few months anyway to get the plants up and running so it's very higher priority to make the decision, which we have not made yet. But I think it's safe to think about some time toward the middle of next year if the
componenttext: We're looking at an opening. It takes a few months anyway to get the plants up and running so it's very higher priority to make the decision, which we have not made yet. But I think it's safe to think about some time toward the middle of next year if the market conditions continue to support the opening. So we have this. But Q2, Q3, are a good time frame and we still have to decide what percentage of the plant we would be launching. So I'd say, Michael will turn his team, most likely some time in the first 3 months of next year to contemplate a midyear opening of the plant.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then final question, on the acquisition strategy that you outlined here. In the past, obviously, the BioPolymers business was always an area where we're trying to find acquisitions and we've done at least one actually. The other area was identif
componenttext: Okay, and then final question, on the acquisition strategy that you outlined here. In the past, obviously, the BioPolymers business was always an area where we're trying to find acquisitions and we've done at least one actually. The other area was identified as crop production. But now you're saying that you're going to be doing more kind of inlicensing and maybe expanding the pace of what you're doing already, but you've been pretty categorical about not growing that business to even bolt-on acquisitions. Can you give us some flavor for why the thinking has changed and what's become less attractive about growing the business through M&A?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, first of all, let me make sure I'm very clear on this business. It is a critical business from a growth and earnings standpoint. So external growth of this business is absolutely critical. Now here is what is the thinking behind the decision. First o
componenttext:
Yes, first of all, let me make sure I'm very clear on this business. It is a critical business from a growth and earnings standpoint. So external growth of this business is absolutely critical. Now here is what is the thinking behind the decision. First of all, we do have a very high quality franchise. Our earnings and repeated performance demonstrate that we do have a unique business model, which is very sustainable. When we look at other companies, which could be potentially at some point variable for acquisition, it is very hard to find any company which is close to the performance of business model we do have in our Ag business, and we are concerned, I am concerned about potentially having a negative impact if we do acquisition on the quality and the performance of this franchise. These especially coming with the type of multiple which we're seeing today in the [Audio Gap] world, which are very high and I'm just afraid we would not get the right type of returns, taking into account the performance of our business. It also comes from the fact that the agricultural team has uncovered maybe stronger way to grow and I'm talking about smaller transaction. Smaller transaction is they might involve less of occurrence because it will not be straight acquisition of company but more acquisition of product line. So it's licensing and it's one of it. Joined technology provides one of it. But think about companies which might have product line, which would have a lot of synergies of our product and might not be as critical for them. We would be willing to make significant investments to bring these in our portfolio, and we believe it's a safer way to protect the quality to our franchise. Now we will uncover more about the size, but the actual growth in Ag through this process could be significant by no mean we are reducing that through growth. It's a pretty ambitious but very different approach in a cheaper approach with higher return to do it. 
All right, I think I'm going to go now in my very quick closing remarks. First of all, I would like to thank everyone for your time and attention. We look forward to seeing you at our investor conference on December 2 in New York. And this concludes our call. Thank you very much.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call for FMC Corporation. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I will turn the conference over to Mr. Brennen Arndt. Mr. Arndt, sir, you may begin.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call for FMC Corporation. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I will turn the conference over to Mr. Brennen Arndt. Mr. Arndt, sir, you may begin.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome everyone to FMC's Third Quarter 2010 Conference Call and Webcast. Pierre Brondeau, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer will begin our call today with a review of third quarter performance. Pierre will turn the call over
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome everyone to FMC's Third Quarter 2010 Conference Call and Webcast. Pierre Brondeau, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer will begin our call today with a review of third quarter performance. Pierre will turn the call over to Kim Foster, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, for a report on our financial position, as well as provide our outlook for the full year and fourth quarter 2010. Pierre will then share with you our longer-term perspective for FMC in the context of the Vision 2015 initiative we launched last July. We'll complete the call by taking your questions. 
Joining Pierre and Kim for our Q&A session will be Milton Steele, Vice President and General Manager, Agricultural Products; Ted Butz, Vice President and General Manager, Specialty Chemicals; Michael Wilson, Vice President and General Manager, Industrial Chemicals; and Mark Douglas, Vice President, Global Services and International Development. 
A reminder today that our discussion will include certain statements that are forward-looking and subject to various risks and uncertainties concerning specific factors that are summarized in FMC's 2009 Form 10-K, our most recent Form 10-Q and other SEC filings. This information represents our best judgment based on today’s information. Actual results may vary based upon these risks and uncertainties.
Also, during the conference call, we will refer to certain non-GAAP financial terms. On the FMC website, available at fmc.com, you will find the definition of these terms under the heading entitled Glossary of Financial Terms. We have also provided our 2010 outlook statement and reconciliation to GAAP of the non-GAAP figures that we will use today.
It's now my pleasure to turn the call over to Pierre Brondeau. Pierre?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brennen, and good morning, everyone. As you saw in our earnings release, we delivered strong third quarter performance at the high-end of our expected range. We realized strong double-digit earnings growth and significant margin expansion acros
componenttext:
Thank you, Brennen, and good morning, everyone. As you saw in our earnings release, we delivered strong third quarter performance at the high-end of our expected range. We realized strong double-digit earnings growth and significant margin expansion across all 3 segments. Third quarter earnings increased 28% to $1.14 per diluted share before restructuring and other income and charges on revenue of $772 million, which increased 8%. 
In Agricultural Products, sales increased 15% to $309 million, while earnings increased 27% to $75 million, consistent with our expectation. In Specialty Chemicals, sales increased 5% to $202 million with earnings up 15% to $47 million, again in line with our expectations. And Industrial Chemicals, sales increased 3% to $262 million and earnings were up 45% to $30 million, which was better than we expected.
On a GAAP basis, we reported net income of $83 million or $1.13 per diluted share. GAAP earnings in the current quarter included the net charge of $0.6 million after tax or $0.01 per diluted share versus the net charge of $37 million after tax of $0.51 per diluted share in the prior year quarter. With that reconciliation, our non-GAAP earnings were $1.14 per diluted share in the current quarter, an increase of 28% versus $0.89 per diluted share in the quarter of 2009.
Going forward, our outlook is for the strong performance to continue for the balance of the year. In the fourth quarter, we expect earnings of $0.95 to $1.05 per diluted share before restructuring and other income and charges. And for the full year 2010, we have raised the midpoint of our guidance with our expectation for earnings before restructuring and other income and charges to $4.07 to $4.08 earnings per diluted share, a 14% increase above last year at the midpoint of this range.
Let me now take a more detailed look at third quarter performance in each of our operating segments. First, in Agricultural Products. As I noted a moment ago, revenue increased 15% versus the prior year quarter. This was driven by higher sales in all regions. In Latin America, the sales increase reflected improved market conditions and growth in planted acres for key crops. In Asia, sales were up in most key countries, reflecting improved market conditions, the introductions of new product and favorable currency impact. Sales in North America improved due to a strong demand in the cotton market, partially offset by lower price pressure in the residue market. Sales in Europe increased as a result of higher herbicide sales and a sheep wool sales from the second quarter due to the delayed growing seasons. Agricultural segment earnings increased 27% to $75 million, driven by the sales gain and favorable product and geographic mix, partially offset by increased spending on new product introductions and growth initiatives.
Moving now to Specialty Chemicals. Revenue in this segment of $202 million was 5% higher than the prior year quarter, driven by the continued demand recovery in lithium primaries, higher volumes and selling prices in lithium specialty and volume growth in BioPolymer. Segment earnings of $47 million increased 15% above prior year, driven by the sales gain, favorable mix in BioPolymer's food ingredient business and continuous productivity improvement, partially offset by higher raw material cost. In lithium, upstream primaries volumes increased substantially versus prior year driven by strong battery in Asian demand. In downstream specialties, growth was driven by higher volumes in selling price in butyllithium. Lithium earnings increased significantly versus last year as a result of the sales gain and continuous productivity improvements. In BioPolymer, third quarter revenue increased as a result of volume growth in food and pharmaceutical businesses. BioPolymer earnings increased significantly versus a year ago, driven by volume gains, favorable product mix in food ingredients and reduced operating costs, partially offset by higher raw material costs.
Moving to Industrial Chemicals. Sales of $262 million increased 3% from the prior year quarter. Volume gains in soda ash, especially in export market and in North America and European peroxygen markets were partially offset by lower selling price. Segment earnings of $30 million increased 45% versus last year as a result of the volume gains, lower raw material and energy cost and lower plant outage costs. This year-on-year performance exceeded our earlier guidance for the quarter in part because we chose to shift to the fourth quarter some outages we've usually planned for the third quarter for commercial and operational reasons.
In soda ash, volumes continued to rebound significantly above last year. In the domestic markets, our mid-single digit volume growth year-to-date is in line with the demand recovery in flat glass, detergents and chemicals market. And in the export markets of Asia and Latin America, our demand growth is more robust, up approximately 50% year-to-date versus last year resulting from higher market demand and the success of ANSAC share recapture strategy. ANSAC primary competitors in this export market, Chinese soda ash exporters, have reduced export volume by approximately 35% versus last year. Continued constraint on Chinese export is expected due to input cost pressure and government-imposed energy restrictions. This strong rebound have moved U.S. producers to near full utilization. We expect tight conditions to continue across the balance of this year and into next year. 
In reflection of these industry conditions, FMC announced a $10 per ton price increase in May for the domestic market. And last month, we announced another $10 per ton price increase. However, given the full year nature of our domestic contract pricing, no material increase will be achieved prior to January 1 next year. Our peroxygens business performed well in the quarter, delivering a significant earnings increase driven by volume growth and improved mix due to growth in our specialties business. In specialties, our environmental solar mediation, food safety and oil field businesses all contributed strongly to the earnings increase.
I will now turn the call over to Kim Foster for a review of corporate financial items and to provide our outlook for the balance of the year. Kim?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Pierre, and good morning, everyone. Continuing on third quarter items, corporate expense was $16 million as compared to $10 million a year ago. Interest expense net was $10 million versus $6 million in the prior year quarter. On September 30, 2010
componenttext:
Thanks, Pierre, and good morning, everyone. Continuing on third quarter items, corporate expense was $16 million as compared to $10 million a year ago. Interest expense net was $10 million versus $6 million in the prior year quarter. On September 30, 2010, gross consolidated debt was $668 million and debt net of cash was $400 million. For the quarter, depreciation and amortization was $33 million and capital expenditures were $36 million.
Moving to free cash flow, we are maintaining our cash flow projection for the full year 2010 at approximately $200 million. As a reminder, free cash flow is defined as after acquisitions but before cash returned to shareholders. Regarding share repurchases during the quarter, we repurchased 156,000 shares for a total value of $10 million. The share repurchases we have made year-to-date have essentially offset dilution from the issuance of restricted stock and stock option exercises. The existing board authorization has $155 million remaining. 
Let me now provide more detail regarding the outlook for the balance of the year that Pierre summarized earlier. For the full year 2010, we've raised the midpoint of our guidance with our expectation of earnings before restructuring and other income and charges of $4.70 to $4.80 per diluted share, a 14% increase above last year at the midpoint of this range. We expect the Agricultural Products to deliver its seventh straight year of record earnings, with segment earnings up in the mid-single digits while increasing investment in innovation and continuing to deliver high profit margins.
In Specialty Chemicals, earnings are projected to increase by approximately 20%. We expect BioPolymer to achieve its sixth straight year of record earnings and lithium to realize significant earnings improvement through the robust demand recovery in lithium primaries. In Industrial Chemicals, we project earnings to increase by approximately 35% driven by a significant volume rebound and favorable raw material costs, only partially offset by reduced selling prices.
Moving to our outlook for the fourth quarter, we expect earnings before restructuring and other income and charges of $0.95 to $1.05 per diluted share. In Agricultural Products, we look for fourth quarter earnings to be up approximately 20%, driven by continued growth in Brazil. In Specialty Chemicals, earnings are expected to be up approximately 30%, driven by volume growth across the segment and favorable mix in food ingredients, partially offset by higher raw material costs. In Industrial Chemicals, we expect earnings to decline approximately 20% primarily due to the move from the third quarter to the fourth quarter of the planned maintenance outages including the successful completion of the boiler repair at our Wyoming soda ash facility early in the fourth quarter. Commercial performance in the segment will continue to benefit from higher volumes and lower raw material and energy costs, only partially offset by reduced selling prices relative to a year ago.
With that, I'll now turn the call back to you, Pierre.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kim. I would like to share with you the longer-term perspective for FMC in the context of the Vision 2015 initiative we launched in July. As you know, we will provide you with a more in-depth review of Vision 2015 at our investor conference on
componenttext:
Thank you, Kim. I would like to share with you the longer-term perspective for FMC in the context of the Vision 2015 initiative we launched in July. As you know, we will provide you with a more in-depth review of Vision 2015 at our investor conference on December 2 in New York, but I want to take this opportunity to preview its key elements. 
In short, Vision 2015 is about driving strong shareholder value creation by aligning our organization around clear and ambitious financial growth. By 2015, we envision an FMC that generate $5 billion of annual revenue, delivers improved sustained EBIT margin greater than 20%, demonstrate significantly less earnings volatility, sustain high returns on investment capital and provide strong free cash flow. We have a well-defined executable plan to grew our current businesses above $4 billion in revenue through organic initiatives. The result that, by itself, would significantly enhance shareholder return.
On top of that, we expect external growth initiatives, including acquisition, to increase our total revenue to $5 billion by 2015. We have developed a focused disciplined plan that reduces the risk normally inherent in external growth and believe this target is achievable. Importantly, we believe that our external growth target will not require all of our expected free cash flow and debt capacity. As a result, we fully intend to return a meaningful amount of cash to shareholders. 
Starting in the fourth quarter, we intend to repurchase $100 million in stock in open market transactions under our existing board authorization. We are launching Vision 2015 from a position of strength. FMC's recent past has been a period of strong financial performance. Most of our businesses now enjoy margins and return on net assets well above peer levels. FMC is also strongly positioned financially with a liquid balance sheet, with high operating ROI and substantial free cash flow. Our performance created attractive shareholder value over the period of 2002 to 2009. FMC delivered 17% compound total annual total shareholder return, putting us in the top quartile of our industry. Our goal is to sustain this high level of performance and to drive even greater value creation by growing our leadership position, increasing our reach, leveraging the size and scale of our operations and reducing cost, more actively managing our portfolio of businesses and maintaining a highly disciplined focus on our use of cash. 
Let me briefly touch on each of these strategic elements. First, growing our leadership position. We will strengthen and build FMC's leadership positions in our current core businesses and market. We will not seek to add the new business leg to our portfolio. We strongly believe our portfolio of businesses and the markets they serve are attractive and provide ample opportunity for profitable growth over the planned horizon.
Second, increasing FMC's reach. We intend to accelerate the global growth of many of our businesses with a particular focus on rapidly developing economies or RDEs. Our goal is for RDEs to contribute roughly half of FMC sales by 2015. 
Third, we seek to capture the value of common ownership by shifting from a novelly decentralized model to one that better leverages the size and scale of our company in a few key areas to realize greater savings and operational efficiencies while maintaining autonomy and accountability in the business units. Prior area include optimizing procurement and our supply chain. And as I previously stated, building the essential infrastructure in RDEs.
Fourth,  we will move actively -- we will more actively manage our portfolio, while nearly all of our current businesses and divisions are well positioned for sustained growth, we will continue to assess their performance and address any issues hindering profitability for growth. And finally, we will maintain a highly disciplined and focused approach to cash deployment.
During the 2010 to 2015 period, we expect to generate cumulative excess cash of approximately $2 billion after taxes, capital spending and regular dividends. Our balance sheet strength also gives us the opportunity to increase debt while maintaining the strong investment grade credit rating. Overall, we expect to have approximately $3 billion in available excess cash to be deployed. As I've noted, we intend to return a meaningful amount of cash to shareholders over this period as our external growth strategy will not consume all the available cash.
Those of you who have followed up FMC the past will recognize the Vision 2015 both the elements of continuity and important element of change. Let me begin with what will be different. There are 4 key change element that we expect will contribute significantly to the success of Vision 2015. First, external growth in our Ag business will be driven by smaller transaction, including product line acquisition, licensing, development investments and alliances and gaining access to third-party active ingredients. We will not pursue transformational or bolt-on acquisitions.
Second, BioPolymer's food ingredients business is a top priority for M&A. We will proactively seek bolt-on acquisition targets to extend into other texturant product, build on our position revenue in developing economies and evaluate entry into additional specialty ingredients. Third, soda ash and peroxygens are highly valued contributor and key long-term components of the FMC portfolio. We will retain these businesses as core parts of our portfolio.
Fourth, as previously mentioned, given our expected free cash flow, debt capacity and expected cash needs, we plan to return a significant amount of cash to shareholders. While these 4 elements each represent a degree of change in our direction, the forward focus of our business unit provides continuity. While we provide more detail at our December 2 investor conference, I want to mention some initiatives here. 
Our products will focus on maintaining premium margin through the continued successful execution of its current business model. Specifically, its focus on niche crops, selective penetration of larger crops and its variable manufacturing paradigm. Market innovation, improving the productivity of product division export and reinforcing a differentiated position to selective external growth are also critical element to achieve its margin objectives. In addition, we will actively explore opportunity in adjacent spaces in order to expand our technology platform. 
Within Specialty Chemicals, as I mentioned earlier, BioPolymer's food ingredients business is a priority area for bolt-on M&A. While it continues to pursue attractive opportunities for organic growth and across the customer and technology development with an increased focus on RDEs, especially China, India and other parts of Asia. Our intent is to maintain and strengthen its industry-leading margin while pursuing external growth.
In BioPolymer's pharmaceutical business, our strategy priorities are to maintain our leading positions, increase our presence in RDEs and very selectively explore adjacent products and markets including positioning ourselves differently in the value chain. Lithium is also positioned to become a major growth platform and we will focus on continuing organic growth in this attractive end market, enhancing margins and preparing its business for significant growth by mid-decade.
Our refocused Industrial Chemicals business will produce higher margin, stronger cash generation and less earnings volatility. Our soda ash business is a highly valued component of our portfolio with low volatility, strong profitability and high returns on capital employed. Soda ash will focus on maintaining leadership in a rebounding market and continuing to work to improve our cost position through operational excellence initiative and advancement in process technology. We consider our Granger facility a strategic asset and will deploy its capacity as needed to meet growing demand. 
In peroxygen, we will significantly shift our product mix to specialty products and markets, including environmental and anti-microbial applications. We will consolidate our North American and European businesses into a single global business to leverage scale and accelerate the penetration of specialty initiative across geographies. By 2015, we expect the majority of our sales to be generated in specialty applications.
Across the businesses of Industrial Chemicals, we have some promising early-stage environmental solutions offering. We currently have 2 potentially significant applications nearing commercialization. Hydrogen peroxide for NOx control peracetic acid biocide for shale gas consumers. Though each -- it depends on successful field testing and regulatory outcomes. This, plus a few other potential products across the portfolio, could provide the foundation for a significant environmental solutions growth platform longer term. 
As we have discussed in recent quarters, we are in the process of restructuring Foret down to its profitable core through the exit of the phosphate business and the consolidation of its peroxygen business into FMC peroxygens. The restructuring of phosphate is critical to achieving our vision for Industrial Chemicals segment that achieve and sustain the higher operating margin and significantly reduced earnings volatility. We are currently pursuing 2 parallel paths with respect to phosphate and are working hard to achieve resolution in the coming weeks. Therefore, we are not in a position to provide any more detail today.
To sum up, I hope this review has provided a good roadmap for you to begin thinking about FMC's future. Through Vision 2015, we have identified clear strategic priorities in the associated financial goals. To reiterate again, a few key points, in Agricultural Products, we will not pursue transformational or bolt-on transaction, but we'll pursue growth opportunities through small transaction and by building on our innovation strategy. BioPolymer's food ingredient business is our #1 priority for bolt-on M&A and product line extension is mission-critical. Soda ash and peroxygen are attractive businesses, and we believe there are substantial opportunities to drive earnings in both businesses.
Finally, given FMC's expected future cash generation and investment needs, we will be focused on disciplined cash deployment including returning cash to shareholders. This will start in the fourth quarter, as I said, when we intend to repurchase $100 million in stock in open market transaction under our existing board authorization. 
This is truly an exciting time for FMC. We look forward to sharing our Vision 2015 with you at our investor conference on December 2 in New York.
With that in mind, in today's Q&A session, we would ask that you focus your questions on our third quarter results, fourth quarter outlook and only general question regarding our strategic direction. We will be happy to address more specific Vision 2015 questions on December 2 in New York. 
With that, I thank you for your time and attention, I'll be happy to take your questions. Operator please?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  Your first question comes from the line of Frank Mitsch from BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you look, Frank -- if you look at -- if you remember, we were planning, as we said in the second quarter call, about $7 million spending for the boiler repair and plant outage. We were expecting a large part of that to be in the third quarter and the s
componenttext: If you look, Frank -- if you look at -- if you remember, we were planning, as we said in the second quarter call, about $7 million spending for the boiler repair and plant outage. We were expecting a large part of that to be in the third quarter and the smaller part to be in the fourth quarter. For operational and commercial reasons, we have shifted that toward the beginning of the fourth quarter. The good news is, all is well. The boiler is repaired and functioning and the outage is behind us. We do believe that the range we gave to you of $4 million to $7 million is on the high side of that range spent over 2 quarters, and it's about 1/3 in the third quarter and about 2/3 in the fourth quarter.

componenttext: All right, terrific. And then lastly, I noted that in the Ag business, you have sales moving up for the year in excess of what your EBIT will be moving up. Can you just spend another minute or 2 talking about why that would be?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Frank. There is 2 major reasons for which we do have such a situation. First of all, remember that business from an earnings standpoint was penalized in the first half of the year on inventory cost. And there was about a $20 million over 2 quarters o
componenttext: Yes, Frank. There is 2 major reasons for which we do have such a situation. First of all, remember that business from an earnings standpoint was penalized in the first half of the year on inventory cost. And there was about a $20 million over 2 quarters of penalty at the gross margin level. It's purely accounting. There is nothing to do with the quality of the performance or the sales or the operations of -- or the operations of the business. Second of all, we have made a very conscious decision to increase our spending in market innovation and technology innovation for growth. So we knew getting into the year, that those 2 reasons would create lower earning growth than sales growth. We do believe it's going to be a situation that's going to change where we will be starting next year, able to leverage top line growth into earning growth.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John McNulty from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John McNulty from Credit Suisse.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a few quick questions. On the Specialty Chemical front, with what we've seen in terms of lithium volumes and maybe the pricing coming back, and BioPolymer is looking like it was pretty good. I'm surprised the growth was maybe as moderate as it was in
componenttext: Just a few quick questions. On the Specialty Chemical front, with what we've seen in terms of lithium volumes and maybe the pricing coming back, and BioPolymer is looking like it was pretty good. I'm surprised the growth was maybe as moderate as it was in the quarter. Can you give us a little bit of color as to what might have driven that?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, you're talking about the growth year-on-year sequentially?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Year-on-year, yes. There was a capital of a -- actually, there was one main reason. If you look at our Specialty Chemical business, this business is made of 3 businesses. We do have the lithium business, we have the food business and we have the pharma bu
componenttext: Year-on-year, yes. There was a capital of a -- actually, there was one main reason. If you look at our Specialty Chemical business, this business is made of 3 businesses. We do have the lithium business, we have the food business and we have the pharma business. Year-on-year, the lithium business was up 14%, well within expectations. The pharma business was up 9%, well within expectations. The food business was only up 4%, which is below what we would be expecting. And there is one main reason for that. As you know, we had an acquisition we made of ISP and this year, we completed the integration process of that acquisition, creating some lower capacity because we faced some problem in transferring the process and moving that to our North American plant. So what happened is in this quarter, we were limited in our growth, not by customer demand. We actually were operating through the quarter with a significant backlog that we were limited in our ability to supply product to customers because of those integration issues. We do have worked those issues very hard, and we do believe that they are very close to being behind us, and we can resume normal growth very quickly.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Now that color is very helpful. Second question would be in the soda ash business, and maybe it's 2 parts to it. First part would be on the pricing. I know you've announced a couple of price increases. Given kind of what is going on in Asia w
componenttext: Okay, great. Now that color is very helpful. Second question would be in the soda ash business, and maybe it's 2 parts to it. First part would be on the pricing. I know you've announced a couple of price increases. Given kind of what is going on in Asia with the weakness -- or weakness in supply outside of Asia because of the energy issues that you mentioned, how should we think about pricing in terms of where it can go and if the full increase that you've announced will -- are likely to stick or how should we think about that?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, I mean, let's break it down into 2 categories. There is the domestic market and, as we said, we have 2 increase for a total of $20 per ton. And ANSAC announced a little while ago a $30 per ton increase for our export market. Now for the domestic ma
componenttext: First, I mean, let's break it down into 2 categories. There is the domestic market and, as we said, we have 2 increase for a total of $20 per ton. And ANSAC announced a little while ago a $30 per ton increase for our export market. Now for the domestic market, as we said before, we are operating very near to full capacity, so we are just getting right now into contract negotiations. It's always hard before you negotiate your contract to know where you will end up and how much of this price increase we'll see. Nevertheless, looking at the near full capacity utilization in North America, we are getting into those negotiation quite confident. Regarding the export market, we do have many reasons to believe that ANSAC will be successful. I think we are seeing more and more limitation on Chinese export capacity because of their pricing and cost situation. So we do believe that the price increase ANSAC is pushing will result in some success. Once again, this price increase for us applied to Latin America, where most of the contracts are annual, so hard to know until we get closer to January. We might actually, in Asia, actually in China, see some impact of this price increase because we are operating on shorter-term contract in Asia, and we might be able to see some improvement on the pricing situation for export in Asia outside of China. But really, the full impact, John, we will know that when we get closer to the month of December, January.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: At this stage, I think life is going to change more for Solvay than it's going to change for us. We keep on going. We do believe we are in a very strong position. ANSAC is doing a tremendous job in the -- on the export. So we are not looking at that as a very threatening or very much changing of the situation.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kevin, I don't have an exact number for you in terms of the amount of capacity that's been taken offline. Sometimes, it's hard to track. We do know that at least 2 significant plants have been taken down, we believe, permanently and others have been curta
componenttext: Kevin, I don't have an exact number for you in terms of the amount of capacity that's been taken offline. Sometimes, it's hard to track. We do know that at least 2 significant plants have been taken down, we believe, permanently and others have been curtailed, And a lot of this has to do with China and its targets for energy usage as a percentage of GDP. So there were a lot of restrictions in the third quarter. I think, overall, China is operating at about 80% capacity utilization. But if you go into some of these provinces where they're really up against their targets, capacity in some plants has been ratcheted back to 30%, 60%. So it's really hard to judge overall. What we do know is that exports from China year-on-year are down some 35%. So between the energy restrictions and between their inability to compete on price with ANSAC, there has been a significant impact in terms of our influence in the export market.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I look at the composition of your soda ash sales, Michael, what's the approximate split of U.S. versus exports, say, year-to-date or over the last year or so?
componenttext: If I look at the composition of your soda ash sales, Michael, what's the approximate split of U.S. versus exports, say, year-to-date or over the last year or so?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: About 52% of our total sales are in export markets, either through ANSAC or direct.
componenttext: About 52% of our total sales are in export markets, either through ANSAC or direct.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, and where is freight running to Asia these days?
componenttext: Okay, and where is freight running to Asia these days?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure that I have an exact number, but freight has come down to Asia, which has benefited ANSAC. And as we look forward to 2011, we think freight again is going to be beneficial to ANSAC as well as our exports to Europe.
componenttext: I'm not sure that I have an exact number, but freight has come down to Asia, which has benefited ANSAC. And as we look forward to 2011, we think freight again is going to be beneficial to ANSAC as well as our exports to Europe.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last question, if I may, for Pierre. You made it clear that BioPolymers is your top priority for M&A. I was wondering if you could just talk about the criteria for acquisitions that you're evaluating in terms of any color on timeframes for
componenttext: Okay. And then last question, if I may, for Pierre. You made it clear that BioPolymers is your top priority for M&A. I was wondering if you could just talk about the criteria for acquisitions that you're evaluating in terms of any color on timeframes for earnings accretion, multiple ranges, size of deals, that sort of thing?

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. First of all, size of deal, we are looking in bolt-on, looking at all these expansions. So I would say anything from companies which are running 10 million barrels in sales with good growth potential or international expansion to $200 million, $300 m
componenttext: Yes. First of all, size of deal, we are looking in bolt-on, looking at all these expansions. So I would say anything from companies which are running 10 million barrels in sales with good growth potential or international expansion to $200 million, $300 million, $400 million in sales will be the kind of bolt-on acquisition we would be looking at. What we would like to expect from a multiple standpoint is to make acquisition where past synergies multiple do not create dilution. And of course, we like acquisition to be accretive very quickly first year. And if not first year, year or 2 at the latest. From a strategy standpoint, we are looking at acquisition. If you look, we have product line in the texturant business where we do have high market share in niche area where we are very strong but pretty much limiting our growth to whatever market growth we have. So our intent -- and we believe we could gain share at critical customers if we wouldn't increase our position in the texturant market with other technologies than the one we do have today. So that's going to be our priority. But once again, we've thought through that very carefully. It's going to be small companies feeding our strategy. We are not going for, any mean, for last transformational deal. We do not believe it would fit our strategy and it could dilute our successful business model.

headline: FMC Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
